docs.title: CAPI + vSphere UAT Cluster
docs.text: This documentation covers a complete, field-tested setup of a Kubernetes workload cluster on vSphere using Cluster API.

docs.title: High-level outcome
docs.text:
• One control-plane node and N worker nodes created via CAPI MachineDeployments.
  • API Server VIP provided by kube-vip (192.168.35.100) and a DNS record kube-api-server.uat.local.
  • Node IPs allocated from InClusterIPPool (tmsnw-pool) via addressesFromPools.
  • Guest networking stabilized by defining the default route (and metric) in the CAPV network device spec.

docs.title: Why this matters
docs.text:
Cluster API is extremely deterministic when three pillars are correct:

  1. vSphere primitives are accurate (template, folder, resource pool, datastore, network)
  2. Guest bootstrap is healthy (cloud-init runs, routes exist, kubeadm succeeds)
  3. Reachability exists between:
  4. management cluster -> workload VIP:6443
  5. workload nodes -> VIP:6443 (for kubeadm join)
  6. workload nodes -> DNS/NTP/package repos (if needed)

If any of those are missing, you’ll see the classic pattern: - Control plane VM exists and is ready in CAPV - Machines/VSphereMachines for workers exist but remain Pending - Controllers log cluster is not reachable: ... connect: no route to host

Continue to Architecture to understand the data plane + control plane flows.

docs.title: 1) Management cluster (CAPI management plane)
docs.text:
The management cluster hosts the controllers that reconcile the desired state:

  • capi-controller-manager (core CAPI)
  • capv-controller-manager (Cluster API Provider vSphere)
  • capi-kubeadm-bootstrap-controller-manager
  • capi-kubeadm-control-plane-controller-manager
  • capi-ipam-in-cluster (if using InClusterIPPool / IPAddressClaims)

docs.title: 2) Workload cluster (your target cluster)
docs.text: Provisioned by the management cluster: - Control plane: KubeadmControlPlane (replicas: 1 in this build) - Workers: MachineDeployment (replicas: 2 in this build)

docs.title: 3) vSphere objects created/consumed
docs.text:
• Template VM: Alma-Clusterconfigtemplate
  • Folder: /Eshare-SRVs/vm/UAT-Servers/ClusterServers
  • ResourcePool: /Eshare-SRVs/host/192.168.150.16/Resources/CAPI_ClusterRP
  • Datastore: R740xd-datastore1
  • Network/Portgroup: TMSNW

docs.title: 4) API VIP (kube-vip)
docs.text:
• VIP: 192.168.35.100
  • DNS: kube-api-server.uat.local -> 192.168.35.100
  • Port: 6443
  • Runs as a static pod on control-plane via /etc/kubernetes/manifests/kube-vip.yaml
  • Uses ARP mode (vip_arp=true) in this environment.

docs.title: Management cluster -> Workload cluster
docs.text:
• CAPV controllers try to contact https://kube-api-server.uat.local:6443
  • If the VIP is not routable, controllers repeatedly log no route to host and workers won’t join.

docs.title: Workload nodes -> API VIP
docs.text:
• Worker kubeadm join also targets the VIP
  • If the node has no default route (missing gateway), it cannot reach VIP or DNS => join fails

docs.title: Failure modes that look like CAPV issues but are actually networking
docs.text:
• VM has an IP (from IPAM) but cannot ping gateway
  • ip route shows no default via ...
  • nmtui shows gateway empty
  • CAPV logs show cluster is not reachable

docs.title: 🛠 Dockerfile Best Practices
docs.text: Creating efficient, secure, and maintainable Dockerfiles is essential for performance and reproducibility. Below are recommended best practices:

docs.title: 1. Choose a Minimal Base Image
docs.text:
• Use official minimal images like alpine or debian-slim when possible.

  • Avoid bloated base images to reduce image size and vulnerabilities.

Docker
FROM node:20-alpine

docs.title: 2. Leverage Layer Caching
docs.text:
• Place commands that change least at the top of the Dockerfile.

  • Group RUN instructions to minimize image layers.

Docker
RUN apt-get update && \
    apt-get install -y curl && \
    rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

docs.title: 3. Use .dockerignore
docs.text:
• Prevent unnecessary files from being copied into the image.
Text Only
node_modules
.git
*.log
Dockerfile

docs.title: 4. Avoid Installing Unnecessary Packages
docs.text:
• Keep your image clean and secure.

  • Use --no-install-recommends with apt.

Docker
RUN apt-get install --no-install-recommends -y python3

docs.title: 5. Use Multi-Stage Builds
docs.text:
• Compile or build in one stage, copy only what’s needed to final image.
Docker
FROM golang:1.20 AS builder
WORKDIR /app
COPY . .
RUN go build -o main .

FROM alpine
COPY --from=builder /app/main /main
ENTRYPOINT ["/main"]

docs.title: 6. Set a Non-Root User
docs.text:
• Reduce security risk by not running containers as root.
Docker
RUN addgroup -S appgroup && adduser -S appuser -G appgroup
USER appuser

docs.title: 7. Use COPY Instead of ADD
docs.text: • COPY is more predictable. Use ADD only for auto-extracting archives or remote URLs.

docs.title: 8. Use Labels for Metadata
docs.text:
• Add maintainer, version, description, etc.
Docker
LABEL maintainer="yourname@example.com"
LABEL version="1.0"
LABEL description="My awesome app"

docs.title: 9. Specify Exact Version Numbers
docs.text:
• Helps avoid unexpected updates or changes.
Docker
RUN apt-get install -y nginx=1.18.*

docs.title: 10. Always Use CMD or ENTRYPOINT Correctly
docs.text:
• CMD is the default command.

  • ENTRYPOINT is useful for scripts and passing arguments.

Docker
CMD ["nginx", "-g", "daemon off;"]

docs.title: 📦 Docker Compose Examples and Use Cases
docs.text: Docker Compose is a tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications. It allows you to configure services, networks, and volumes in a single docker-compose.yml file.

docs.title: Sample docker-compose.yml
docs.text:
YAML
version: '3.8'
services:
  web:
    image: nginx:latest
    ports:
      - "8080:80"

  app:
    build: ./app
    volumes:
      - ./app:/usr/src/app
    environment:
      - NODE_ENV=development
    depends_on:
      - db

  db:
    image: postgres:13
    environment:
      POSTGRES_USER: user
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: pass
      POSTGRES_DB: mydb
    volumes:
      - pgdata:/var/lib/postgresql/data

volumes:
  pgdata:

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
Bash
docker-compose up         # Start all services
docker-compose down       # Stop and remove containers, networks, volumes
docker-compose build      # Build all services defined in the file
docker-compose ps         # List running services
docker-compose logs -f    # View logs

docs.title: 🐳 Introduction to Docker
docs.text: Docker is an open-source platform designed to automate the deployment, scaling, and management of applications inside lightweight, portable containers. It enables developers and system administrators to package applications with all their dependencies and run them consistently across different environments.

docs.title: 🚀 Why Docker?
docs.text:
• Portability: Run the same container on any system that supports Docker (Linux, Windows, macOS).
  • Isolation: Containers encapsulate everything needed to run a service without affecting the host.
  • Efficiency: Shares the host OS kernel, making it faster and lighter than traditional virtual machines.
  • Version Control: Docker images can be versioned and stored in registries like Docker Hub or Harbor.
  • CI/CD Integration: Easily integrates with modern DevOps workflows.

docs.title: 🧩 Core Components of Docker
docs.text: Component Description Docker Engine The runtime that builds and runs containers. It includes the Docker daemon (dockerd), REST API, and CLI (docker). Images Immutable templates that contain the application and all dependencies. Created using Dockerfiles. Containers Running instances of images. Each container is isolated and stateless by default. Dockerfile Script used to build Docker images by defining steps, base images, and commands. Docker Compose Tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications using a docker-compose.yml file. Volumes Persistent storage mechanism used by containers to store data outside the container's filesystem. Networks Define communication between containers. Supports bridge, host, overlay, and custom networks. Docker Hub / Registry Repositories to store and share Docker images. Can be public (Docker Hub) or private (Harbor, GitLab, etc.).

docs.title: 🧭 Bubble Tea Architecture Overview

We'll walk through each piece:

Text Only
1. Model (holds state)
2. Msg (represents events)
3. Init() (optional setup, like timers or Cmds)
4. Update() (handles logic, changes model, returns Cmd)
5. View() (renders UI from model)

docs.title: 1️⃣ Model (📦 Application State)
docs.text:
This struct holds the current state of the app: choices, cursor, and selected value.

Go
type model struct {
    cursor   int      // current highlighted item
    choices  []string // menu options
    selected string   // user's final choice
}

docs.title: 📌 What is stored in state?
docs.text:
• The current cursor position (which menu item is selected).

  • The list of choices to display.

  • The selected item (after pressing enter).

docs.title: 2️⃣ Msg (📨 Messages or Events)
docs.text:
We don’t need to define custom messages here because keyboard events come as tea.KeyMsg (a built-in type from Bubble Tea).

You can think of this like:

  • "up" key → move cursor up

  • "down" key → move cursor down

  • "enter" key → select the option

// No need for custom message yet; we use built-in tea.KeyMsg

docs.title: 3️⃣ Init() (🚀 App Initialization)
docs.text:
Runs once when the app starts. You can use it to return an initial Cmd (like a timer or async task). We don’t need that for now, so we return nil.

Go
func (m model) Init() tea.Cmd {
    return nil // no initial command needed
}

docs.title: 4️⃣ Update (🔁 Handles Events, Modifies State)
docs.text:
This is the brain of the application. It receives Msg (like a keypress) and updates the model.

Go
func (m model) Update(msg tea.Msg) (tea.Model, tea.Cmd) {
    switch msg := msg.(type) {
    case tea.KeyMsg:
        switch msg.String() {
        case "up":
            if m.cursor > 0 {
                m.cursor--
            }

        case "down":
            if m.cursor < len(m.choices)-1 {
                m.cursor++
            }

        case "enter":
            m.selected = m.choices[m.cursor]
            return m, tea.Quit // select and quit app
        }
    }

    return m, nil
}

docs.title: ✅ What this does:
docs.text:
• Arrow keys change the cursor position.

  • Enter key saves the selected item and exits the app.

  • Returns updated model and (optionally) a command (Cmd).

docs.title: 5️⃣ View (🖼️ Renders UI from State)
docs.text:
This function draws the screen based on the current state.

Go
func (m model) View() string {
    s := "What do you want to do?\n\n"

    for i, choice := range m.choices {
        cursor := " " // default
        if m.cursor == i {
            cursor = ">" // highlight current item
        }

        s += fmt.Sprintf("%s %s\n", cursor, choice)
    }

    if m.selected != "" {
        s += fmt.Sprintf("\nYou selected: %s\n", m.selected)
    }

    return s
}

docs.title: 6️⃣ Main Function (🚪 Entry Point)
docs.text:
This puts everything together and runs the app.

Go
func main() {
    p := tea.NewProgram(model{
        choices: []string{"Create Bucket", "Delete Bucket", "List Buckets"},
    })

    if err := p.Start(); err != nil {
        fmt.Println("Error running program:", err)
        os.Exit(1)
    }
}

2. User presses ↓ → KeyMsg sent → Update() runs
3. model.cursor updated → View() renders new screen
4. User presses ↵ Enter → Update() sets selection → View shows final message
5. tea.Quit stops the app

docs.title: 🧭 Big Picture: How Bubble Tea Works
docs.text: Bubble Tea uses a Model-Update-View (MUV) architecture — a variant of The Elm Architecture. This helps you write clean, reactive terminal apps.

docs.title: 🔁 The Event Loop in Bubble Tea
docs.text:
Text Only
User Input / Event
       ↓
      Msg
       ↓
  Update(model, msg)
       ↓
 New Model + Cmd
       ↓
   View(model)
       ↓
Render (Terminal Output)

Now let’s go through each of these in depth:

docs.title: 🔹 1. User Input / Events
docs.text:
❓ What is this? This includes:

  • Keyboard input (like pressing ↑ or ↓)

  • Mouse events

  • Timers (like a clock tick every second)

  • Network responses (if you're fetching data)

🎯 Goal: Detect that something happened.

🧠 You don’t process the input directly — instead, Bubble Tea transforms it into a Msg.

docs.title: 🔹 2. Msg (Message)
docs.text:
❓ What is this? It’s a type or struct that represents what happened.

You define a custom Msg type to represent user actions or system events.

✅ Example:

Go
type Msg string

const (
    MsgUp   Msg = "up"
    MsgDown Msg = "down"
)

Bubble Tea sends this Msg into the next stage.

docs.title: 🔹 3. Update(model, msg)
docs.text:
❓ What is this? The Update function handles logic.

You write logic inside Update to:

  • Change the state (i.e., update the model)

  • Optionally trigger side effects like timers or network calls (via Cmd)

✅ Example:

Go
func (m model) Update(msg tea.Msg) (model, tea.Cmd) {
    switch msg := msg.(type) {
    case tea.KeyMsg:
        switch msg.String() {
        case "up":
            m.cursor--
        case "down":
            m.cursor++
        }
    }
    return m, nil
}

🎯 Goal: Return a new model (updated state) and optionally a command (Cmd).

docs.title: 🔹 4. New Model + Cmd
docs.text:
✅ Model: The new application state after handling the message.

✅ Cmd (Command): Tells Bubble Tea to run something asynchronously and return a new Msg later.

Common use cases for Cmd:

  • Wait for a timer and send a tick

  • Make a network request

  • Read a file

  • Animate something

✅ Example:

Go
return m, tea.Tick(time.Second, func(t time.Time) tea.Msg {
    return tickMsg(t)
})

docs.title: 🔹 5. View(model)
docs.text:
❓ What is this? It’s a function that takes your model (state) and returns a string to render in the terminal.

🎯 Goal: Turn state into user interface.

✅ Example:

Go
func (m model) View() string {
    s := "Choose an option:\n\n"
    for i, choice := range m.choices {
        cursor := " " // no cursor
        if m.cursor == i {
            cursor = ">" // highlight
        }
        s += fmt.Sprintf("%s %s\n", cursor, choice)
    }
    return s
}

docs.title: 🔄 Loop Back
docs.text: After rendering, Bubble Tea waits for the next event or message, and the cycle repeats.

docs.title: 🎨 Visual Flow Summary
docs.text:
Text Only
1. User presses key          ⌨️
2. Bubble Tea converts to →  Msg
3. Msg sent to →             Update()
4. Update changes →          Model + optional Cmd
5. View() renders →          New UI based on state
6. Back to waiting for event...

docs.title: 🔍 Real Example Flow
docs.text: Let’s say the user presses the down arrow key.

docs.title: Step-by-step:
docs.text:
1. Key press: "down"

  2. Converted to: tea.KeyMsg{Type: KeyDown}

  3. Update() sees the "down" key and increments m.cursor

  4. New model with updated cursor

  5. View() highlights the next item in the list

  6. Terminal redraws the new screen

docs.title: 🧠 Why This Architecture is Powerful:
docs.text:
• Separation of Concerns: View is only for display. Update is only for logic.

  • Testable: You can test each function easily.

  • Async Friendly: Cmd makes async logic simple without goroutines everywhere.

  • Declarative UI: You describe what the UI should look like based on state.

docs.title: Tea.Cmd
docs.text:
## 📝 Author

Birat Aryal — birataryal.github.io Created Date: 2025-07-07 Updated Date: Monday 7th July 2025 19:18:58 Website - birataryal.com.np Repository - Birat Aryal LinkedIn - Birat Aryal DevSecOps Engineer | System Engineer | Cyber Security Analyst | Network Engineer

docs.title: 📦 What is tea.Cmd?
docs.text:
In Bubble Tea:

Go
type Cmd func() Msg

That means a Cmd is just a function that returns a Msg.

So, when you return a tea.Cmd from either:

  • the Init() function, or

  • the Update() function,

you're telling Bubble Tea:

“Please run this code asynchronously and send its result back into my program as a Msg.”

It's Bubble Tea’s way of handling side effects, like:

  • Fetching data from a file or the network

  • Waiting for a timer

  • Running a background task

  • Listening for input

  • Any asynchronous work that will eventually send data back to your program

docs.title: 🧠 Why is Init() defined like this?
✅ Example with tea.Cmd in Init()
docs.text:
Let's say you want to wait 2 seconds and then show a message.

Go
func (m model) Init() tea.Cmd {
    return tea.Tick(2*time.Second, func(t time.Time) tea.Msg {
        return msgTimePassed{}
    })
}

Here:

  • tea.Tick waits for 2 seconds,

  • then sends msgTimePassed{} to the Update() function,

  • which can then update your model and re-render the screen.

docs.title: 📝 Summary
docs.text:
Function Purpose Return tea.Cmd to... Init() Called once at startup Start async/background work Update() Called on every Msg Trigger new async work View() Returns a string Never returns Cmd

So tea.Cmd is how Bubble Tea does side-effects in a clean, functional way.

docs.text: Comprehensive guide to Git merge strategies, including definitions, command examples, editor behavior, commit history implications, and practical workflows.

docs.title: 🧭 Introduction
docs.text: Git merge strategies determine how changes from one branch are integrated into another. The right strategy depends on whether you want to retain detailed history, squash it, or ignore it entirely.

docs.title: ❓ Why Merging Strategies Matter
docs.text:
• 🔍 Traceable project history

  • 🧘‍♀️ Clean, readable logs

  • 🛠️ Efficient conflict resolution

  • 🤝 Better team collaboration

docs.title: 1. Recursive (Default)
docs.text:
Usage: Most common; works with two branches that have diverged.

Bash
git merge feature/login

docs.title: 2. Resolve
docs.text:
Usage: Simple, two-parent merge; mostly deprecated in favor of recursive.

Bash
git merge -s resolve feature/login

docs.title: 3. Octopus
docs.text:
Usage: Merge multiple branches (no conflicts allowed).

Bash
git merge -s octopus feature1 feature2 feature3

docs.title: 4. Ours
docs.text:
Usage: Use current branch's changes and discard the other.

Bash
git merge -s ours experiment-branch

docs.title: 5. Subtree
docs.text:
Usage: Merging unrelated projects while keeping their directory structures.

Bash
git merge -s subtree project-b

docs.title: 6. Squash ✅
docs.text:
Usage: Flatten all commits from a feature branch into one commit. Great for clean history and PR-based workflows.

Bash
git merge --squash feature/checkout-page

🛠 What happens:

  • Git collects all commits from the feature branch.

  • The code from all those commits is merged into your working directory.

  • A single commit is created (but not yet committed).

You’ll see a text editor (usually Vim or VSCode) open with something like:

Text Only
# This is a combination of 5 commits.
# The first commit's message is:
Add checkout page UI

# The 2nd commit message is:
Implement discount logic

# The 3rd commit message is:
Refactor checkout controller

# Please enter the commit message for your changes.

📝 You can edit this message, summarizing all changes in a single commit:

Text Only
Add complete checkout functionality

- Added UI for checkout
- Implemented coupon/discount logic
- Refactored controller logic

Then commit it manually:

Bash
git commit

🔁 Final result: One new commit is added to the main branch — a flattened, clean version of the entire feature.

🧩 Pro Tip:

  • Combine with git rebase -i to refine history before squashing.

  • Use in PR-based workflows for atomic merges.

docs.title: Fast-forward (--ff)
docs.text:
• Pointer just moves forward (no merge commit).
Strategy Description --ff Moves the branch pointer ahead—no merge commit --no-ff Forces a merge commit—keeps merge info Bash
git merge --ff feature

docs.title: No Fast-forward (--no-ff)
docs.text:
• Always creates a merge commit.
Bash
git merge --no-ff feature

docs.title: 🌍 Real-world Use Cases
docs.text: Scenario Strategy Why Feature branch merge --no-ff Keeps history of the feature Hotfix multiple branches octopus Merge all hotfixes at once Discard experimental code ours Keep current state, mark merge complete Vendor code or repo fusion subtree Preserve separate history in a sub-dir Simplify history for PR --squash Single meaningful commit on main branch Rewriting messy local commits rebase -i Makes feature history clean

Use --squash in conjunction with CI pipelines and PR reviews to reduce commit noise and keep history readable.

  • 🔀 Avoid octopus if there's any chance of a conflict.

  • 🚫 Use ours sparingly—you're discarding someone’s work.

  • 🧰 Document your team strategy in CONTRIBUTING.md.

docs.title: ☸️ Kubernetes Introduction
docs.text: Kubernetes (often abbreviated as K8s) is an open-source container orchestration platform designed to automate the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications. Originally developed by Google and now maintained by the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF), Kubernetes has become the industry standard for managing containerized workloads.

docs.title: 🧩 Why Kubernetes?
docs.text:
Kubernetes solves many common problems in modern cloud-native deployments:

  • 🔁 Automated Rollouts & Rollbacks: Deploy changes gradually and automatically revert if issues are detected.

  • 📦 Service Discovery & Load Balancing: Distribute traffic evenly across healthy pods.

  • ⚖️ Horizontal Scaling: Automatically scale applications based on CPU/memory or custom metrics.

  • ♻️ Self-healing: Replace failed containers, reschedule pods on healthy nodes.

  • 🗂️ Config & Secrets Management: Decouple environment-specific configuration from code.

  • 🔒 RBAC & Network Policies: Secure workloads through fine-grained access control and isolation.

docs.title: 📁 Core Concepts
docs.text:
• Pod: The smallest deployable unit in Kubernetes, which can contain one or more containers.

  • Service: An abstraction that defines a logical set of pods and a policy to access them.

  • Deployment: Manages replica sets to maintain a desired number of pod replicas.

  • ReplicaSet: Ensures a specified number of pod replicas are running at any given time.

  • ConfigMap: Stores non-sensitive configuration data.

  • Secret: Stores sensitive information like passwords, tokens, or SSH keys.

  • Namespace: Provides logical isolation of resources.

  • Volume: Persistent storage abstraction used by pods.

docs.title: 🌎 Kubernetes Use Cases
docs.text:

  • Continuous deployment (CI/CD)

docs.title: Log Rotation Configuration for Servicename
docs.text:
This file defines the log rotation policy for the Servicename service. The configuration is located at:

Text Only
/etc/logrotate.d/Servicename

docs.title: 📄 Configuration Overview
docs.text:
Bash
<location of log>/*.log {
    daily
    create <Permission with umask> <username> <group>
    dateext
    compress
    ifempty
    missingok
    copytruncate
    rotate 7
    postrotate
        # Remove rotated files older than 7 days
        find <location of logs> -type f -mtime +7 -name '*.gz' -delete
    endscript
}

docs.title: 🔧 Explanation of Options
docs.text: Directive Description <location of log>/*.log Path to log files that will be rotated (e.g., /var/log/servicename/*.log) daily Rotate logs on a daily basis create Create a new empty log file after rotation with specific permissions and ownership. Replace <Permission with umask>, <username>, and <group> accordingly (e.g., 0640 servicename adm) dateext Adds the current date to the rotated log filenames instead of a numerical suffix compress Compresses the old log files using gzip ifempty Rotate log files even if they are empty missingok Don't show an error if the log file is missing copytruncate Truncates the original log file after copying it, used for active logs written by running processes rotate 7 Keep the last 7 rotated log files before deletion postrotate ... endscript Executes a script after rotation; here it deletes compressed log files (.gz) older than 7 days

docs.title: 🧹 Log Cleanup
docs.text:
After each rotation, this command will delete compressed (*.gz) log files older than 7 days:

Bash
find <location of logs> -type f -mtime +7 -name '*.gz' -delete

Replace <location of logs> with the correct log directory path (e.g., /var/log/servicename).

docs.title: ✅ Example
docs.text:
If your logs are located at /var/log/servicename/ and owned by user servicename in group adm, an example config might look like:

Bash
/var/log/servicename/*.log {
    daily
    create 0640 servicename adm
    dateext
    compress
    ifempty
    missingok
    copytruncate
    rotate 7
    postrotate
        find /var/log/servicename -type f -mtime +7 -name '*.gz' -delete
    endscript
}

docs.title: 🛠️ Apply and Test
docs.text:
To test this configuration manually:

Bash
logrotate -d /etc/logrotate.d/Servicename   # Dry run
logrotate -f /etc/logrotate.d/Servicename   # Force rotation

docs.title: 🌐 What is NGINX?
docs.text:
NGINX is a high-performance, open-source web server and reverse proxy server, originally designed to handle large numbers of concurrent connections efficiently. Over time, it has evolved into a multifunctional web platform capable of:

  • Serving static content (HTML, CSS, JS, images)
  • Acting as a reverse proxy to forward client requests to backend servers
  • Performing load balancing across multiple upstream servers
  • Managing SSL/TLS termination for encrypted HTTPS traffic
  • Functioning as a content cache to reduce backend load
  • Serving as an API gateway or microservices router
  • Providing rate limiting, IP access control, and security header enforcement

NGINX is widely used by high-traffic websites and containerized applications due to its lightweight, fast, and event-driven architecture.

docs.title: ⚙️ Use Cases of NGINX
docs.text:
Here are common ways NGINX is used in real-world deployments:

  • Web Server – Serve static websites or frontend apps like React/Vue.
  • Reverse Proxy – Forward traffic to internal services running on Node.js, Python, Java, etc.
  • SSL Offloading – Handle HTTPS termination and forward traffic as HTTP to internal apps.
  • Load Balancer – Distribute requests to multiple backend servers using round-robin, IP-hash, or least connections.
  • API Gateway – Route and control microservice traffic.
  • Content Caching – Cache upstream responses to reduce latency and server load.
  • Security Gateway – Enforce access control, headers, IP restrictions, and DDoS protection.

docs.title: 🧩 Built-in NGINX Variables
docs.text:
NGINX provides many predefined variables that can be used in configuration files for logging, routing, proxying, and header manipulation.

docs.title: 📘 SQL Server and Table Insights
docs.text: This document provides a set of SQL queries to explore and audit database objects in a Microsoft SQL Server environment. These queries help verify table sizes, row counts, indexes, procedures, and functions — useful for database health checks, performance tuning, and replication diagnostics.

docs.title: 📋 1. Database Details
docs.text:
This query returns all databases present in the server with its creation date.

SQL
SELECT name, database_id, create_date  

FROM sys.databases;  

GO

docs.title: 📋 2. Database Logical & Physical File Details with Size
docs.text:
This query returns the logical and physical file names, file type (Data/Log), and file size in MB for all databases in the SQL Server instance.

SQL
SELECT
    db.name AS DatabaseName,
    mf.name AS LogicalFileName,
    mf.type_desc AS FileType,
    mf.physical_name AS PhysicalFileName,
    CAST((mf.size * 8.0) / 1024 AS DECIMAL(10,2)) AS SizeMB
FROM 
    sys.master_files mf
INNER JOIN 
    sys.databases db ON db.database_id = mf.database_id
ORDER BY 
    db.name, mf.type_desc;

Note

If Wanted to get the details of the specific database only then add WHERE db.name = 'My_Database'

docs.title: 📋 3. Verify Table Names and Row Counts
docs.text:
This query returns all user tables with their corresponding row counts. It excludes system-generated or temporary tables like dt%.

SQL
SELECT 
    t.NAME AS TableName,
    p.rows AS RowCounts
FROM 
    sys.tables t
INNER JOIN 
    sys.indexes i ON t.OBJECT_ID = i.object_id
INNER JOIN 
    sys.partitions p ON i.object_id = p.OBJECT_ID AND i.index_id = p.index_id
WHERE 
    t.NAME NOT LIKE 'dt%'
    AND i.index_id <= 1
ORDER BY 
    t.name ASC;

docs.title: 📦 4. Get Table Size in MB
docs.text:
This query provides a breakdown of total, used, and unused space (in MB) per table.

SQL
SELECT
    s.Name AS SchemaName,
    t.Name AS TableName,
    p.rows AS NumRows,
    CAST(ROUND((SUM(a.total_pages) / 128.00), 2) AS NUMERIC(36, 2)) AS Total_MB,
    CAST(ROUND((SUM(a.used_pages) / 128.00), 2) AS NUMERIC(36, 2)) AS Used_MB,
    CAST(ROUND((SUM(a.total_pages) - SUM(a.used_pages)) / 128.00, 2) AS NUMERIC(36, 2)) AS Unused_MB
FROM
    sys.tables t
    JOIN sys.indexes i ON t.OBJECT_ID = i.object_id
    JOIN sys.partitions p ON i.object_id = p.OBJECT_ID AND i.index_id = p.index_id
    JOIN sys.allocation_units a ON p.partition_id = a.container_id
    LEFT OUTER JOIN sys.schemas s ON t.schema_id = s.schema_id
WHERE
    t.name NOT LIKE 'dt%'
    AND t.is_ms_shipped = 0
    AND i.object_id > 255
GROUP BY
    t.Name, s.Name, p.Rows
ORDER BY
    Total_MB DESC, t.Name;

Note

If needed to look over specific table then include AND t.name = '<Table Name>' on WHERE condition.

docs.title: ⚙️ 5. List All Stored Procedures
docs.text:
Returns all stored procedures in the database, ordered alphabetically.

SQL
SELECT * 
FROM sys.procedures 
ORDER BY name ASC;

docs.title: 🧮 6. List All User-Defined Functions
docs.text:
Displays scalar (FN, FS), inline table-valued (IF), and multi-statement table-valued (TF) functions with definitions.

SQL
SELECT 
    o.name AS FunctionName,
    o.type_desc AS ObjectType,
    m.definition AS FunctionDefinition
FROM 
    sys.objects o
JOIN 
    sys.sql_modules m ON o.object_id = m.object_id
WHERE 
    o.type IN ('FN', 'IF', 'TF', 'FS', 'FT')
ORDER BY 
    o.name;

docs.title: 🗃 7. List All Indexes
docs.text:
Displays index metadata, including uniqueness, primary key status, and whether the index is disabled.

SQL
SELECT 
    OBJECT_NAME(i.OBJECT_ID) AS TableName,
    i.name AS IndexName,
    i.type_desc AS IndexType,
    i.is_unique AS IsUnique,
    i.is_primary_key AS IsPrimaryKey,
    i.is_unique_constraint AS IsUniqueConstraint,
    i.is_disabled AS IsDisabled
FROM 
    sys.indexes i
INNER JOIN 
    sys.tables t ON i.object_id = t.object_id
WHERE 
    t.NAME NOT LIKE 'dt%'
ORDER BY 
    TableName,
    IndexName;

docs.title: 🔐 Notes and Best Practices
docs.text:
• Most queries exclude system tables (dt%) and system objects (is_ms_shipped = 0).
  • Run these queries in SSMS (SQL Server Management Studio) or any T-SQL-compatible client.
  • Adjust WHERE conditions if you have a different naming convention or wish to include system tables.

docs.title: 🛠 Recommended Use Cases
docs.text:
Tip

  • Before configuring replication or migrating tables.
  • During performance tuning to find large tables or missing indexes.
  • For regular audits and reporting of database object metadata.

docs.title: 🗂 SQL Server Transaction Log (LDF) Truncation Guide
docs.text:
LDF Truncate GuideMDF Truncate Guide

This guide demonstrates how to safely truncate and shrink the transaction log file (LDF) of a SQL Server database using T-SQL. It is useful when the log file grows too large due to:

Use Cases

  • Long-running transactions
  • Replication issues
  • Missing backup chain or disabled log backups

Caution

Always back up your database before performing these actions, especially when changing recovery models.

This guide explains how to safely shrink and truncate the data file (MDF) of a SQL Server database using T-SQL. It is especially useful when:

Use Cases

  • The data file has grown significantly, and unused space is not being reclaimed automatically.
  • Large amounts of data were deleted, archived, or moved.
  • Issues like replication lag or long-running transactions have been resolved.

Warning

Shrinking MDF files should be done cautiously and rarely in production. It can cause index fragmentation and impact performance.

Caution

Always back up your database before performing shrink operations and changing recovery models.

docs.title: 📌 1. Identify MDF and LDF File Names
docs.text:
Tip

Run this query to get the logical and physical file names for your target database:

SQL
USE <YourDatabaseName>;
GO

SELECT 
    name AS LogicalFileName,
    physical_name AS PhysicalFilePath,
    type_desc AS FileType
FROM sys.database_files;

Tip

Replace <YourDatabaseName> with the actual name of your database.

docs.title: 🧾 2. Steps to Truncate and Shrink the Files
docs.text: Follow these steps after identifying the correct file name.

docs.title: ✅ Step 1: Issue Checkpoints
docs.text:
Flush dirty pages to disk before shrinking the database files:

SQL
USE <YourDatabaseName>;
GO

CHECKPOINT;
CHECKPOINT;

docs.title: 🔁 Step 2: Switch Recovery Model to SIMPLE
docs.text:
Temporarily switch to the SIMPLE recovery model to allow truncation:

SQL
ALTER DATABASE <YourDatabaseName>
SET RECOVERY SIMPLE;

docs.title: 📉 Step 3: Shrink the Files
docs.text:
Shrink the transaction log file to a target size (e.g., 1,000 MB = 1 GB):

LDFMDF SQL
DBCC SHRINKFILE (<YourLDFLogicalName>, 1000);  -- Size in MB

Tip

Replace <YourLDFLogicalName> with the actual logical name of the log file.

SQL
DBCC SHRINKFILE (<YourMDFLogicalName>, 1000);  -- Size in MB

Tip

Replace <YourMDFLogicalName> with the actual logical name of the data file.

docs.title: ♻️ Step 4: Revert to FULL Recovery Model
docs.text:
Restore the original recovery model:

SQL
ALTER DATABASE <YourDatabaseName>
SET RECOVERY FULL;

docs.title: 📝 Example (Replace with Your Values)
📌 Notes & Best Practices
docs.text:
🔐 Recommendations

  • Always take a full backup after switching back to FULL to restart the log backup chain.
  • Shrinking should be a one-time operation, not part of regular maintenance.
  • Analyze why the file grew in the first place (e.g., large transactions, replication backlog).
  • Rebuild indexes if fragmentation increases significantly after shrink.

docs.title: 🧭 SQL Server Recovery Models – Overview and Use Cases
docs.text: In SQL Server, Recovery Models determine how transaction logs are maintained and how data recovery works. Choosing the right recovery model is essential for balancing data safety, performance, and storage.

docs.title: 1. 🔁 FULL Recovery Model
docs.text:
Description: All transactions are fully logged. Requires regular transaction log backups.

Use Cases: - Production environments where no data loss is acceptable. - Systems requiring point-in-time recovery (e.g., critical financial or e-commerce databases). - Supports log shipping, database mirroring, replication, and Always On.

Pros: - Complete data recovery possible. - Suitable for high availability and disaster recovery.

Cons: - Log file grows unless regular backups are taken. - Requires more storage for log files.

docs.title: 2. 🧹 SIMPLE Recovery Model
docs.text:
Description: Minimal logging; transaction logs are auto-truncated on checkpoint.

Use Cases: - Dev/test environments where data loss is acceptable. - Data warehouses where point-in-time recovery is not needed. - Short-term temporary databases.

Pros: - Less log maintenance. - Smaller log files.

Cons: - No point-in-time recovery. - Not compatible with log backups, replication, or Always On.

docs.title: 3. ⚖️ BULK-LOGGED Recovery Model
docs.text:
Description: Like FULL model, but allows minimal logging for certain bulk operations.

Use Cases: - Large data loads or index rebuilds where performance is critical. - Temporary switch during ETL or staging jobs.

Pros: - Better performance during bulk inserts, BCP, SELECT INTO, etc. - Still allows recovery to the end of the last log backup (not point-in-time).

Cons: - Point-in-time recovery is not possible during bulk operations. - Not suitable for regular usage unless needed during specific tasks.

docs.title: 🔄 Switching Between Recovery Models
docs.text:
You can change recovery models using:

SQL
ALTER DATABASE <YourDatabaseName> SET RECOVERY SIMPLE;
ALTER DATABASE <YourDatabaseName> SET RECOVERY FULL;
ALTER DATABASE <YourDatabaseName> SET RECOVERY BULK_LOGGED;

docs.title: 📘 MSSQL Replication Debugging Guide
docs.text: This guide documents key SQL queries and commands to monitor, troubleshoot, and optimize Transactional Replication in Microsoft SQL Server, especially when experiencing CPU spikes related to replication activities.

docs.title: 🧠 Overview
docs.text:
This guide is useful if:

  • You have configured transactional replication (e.g., Snapshot and Log Reader Agents are running).
  • You notice daily CPU spikes, especially after adding new tables to replication.
  • You want to analyze replication agent load, job schedules, query performance, and indexing.

docs.title: 🔍 1. Check What Kind of Replication Is Configured
docs.text:
SQL
USE distribution;
GO

SELECT 
    pub.publisher_db,
    pub.publication,
    pub.publication_type,
    CASE pub.publication_type
        WHEN 0 THEN 'Transactional'
        WHEN 1 THEN 'Snapshot'
        WHEN 2 THEN 'Transactional with Updatable Subscriptions (deprecated)'
        WHEN 3 THEN 'Peer-to-Peer Transactional'
        WHEN 4 THEN 'Merge'
        ELSE 'Unknown'
    END AS replication_type
FROM dbo.MSpublications pub;

docs.title: ⏰ 2. Check Replication Job Schedules
docs.text:
SQL
USE msdb;
GO

SELECT 
    j.name AS JobName,
    s.name AS ScheduleName,
    js.next_run_date AS NextRunDate,
    js.next_run_time AS NextRunTime
FROM dbo.sysjobs j
JOIN dbo.sysjobschedules js ON j.job_id = js.job_id
JOIN dbo.sysschedules s ON js.schedule_id = s.schedule_id
WHERE j.name LIKE '%snapshot%' OR j.name LIKE '%logreader%';

Useful to identify when Snapshot or Log Reader Agents run (e.g., at 10:00 AM daily).

docs.title: 🔍 3. Identify Active Replication Agent Queries and High CPU Consumers
a) Monitor live high CPU queries at the peak time
docs.text:
SQL
SELECT 
    r.session_id,
    r.status,
    r.command,
    r.cpu_time,
    r.total_elapsed_time,
    r.start_time,
    t.text AS query_text
FROM sys.dm_exec_requests r
CROSS APPLY sys.dm_exec_sql_text(r.sql_handle) t
ORDER BY r.cpu_time DESC;

docs.title: b) Filter for replication agent queries
docs.text:
SQL
SELECT 
    s.session_id,
    r.status,
    r.command,
    t.text AS query_text,
    r.cpu_time,
    r.start_time
FROM sys.dm_exec_requests r
JOIN sys.dm_exec_sessions s ON r.session_id = s.session_id
CROSS APPLY sys.dm_exec_sql_text(r.sql_handle) t
WHERE s.program_name LIKE '%Repl%';

docs.title: 📋 4. Discover Replication Publications and Subscriptions for DB01, DB02 → CDB
docs.text:
Run this on the distribution database:

SQL
USE distribution;
GO

SELECT 
    a.publisher AS PublisherServer,
    a.publisher_db AS PublisherDB,
    a.publication AS PublicationName,
    s.subscriber AS SubscriberServer,
    s.subscriber_db AS SubscriberDB
FROM MSpublications a
JOIN MSsubscriptions s ON a.publication_id = s.publication_id
WHERE a.publisher_db IN ('DB01', 'DB02')
  AND s.subscriber_db = 'CDB'
ORDER BY a.publisher_db, a.publication;

docs.title: 📤 5. Monitor Pending Replication Commands (Replication Latency)
docs.text:
Using the output from the above query, run for each publication/subscription:

SQL
EXEC sp_replmonitorsubscriptionpendingcmds 
    @publisher = '<PublisherServer>',
    @publisher_db = '<PublisherDB>',
    @publication = '<PublicationName>',
    @subscriber = '<SubscriberServer>',
    @subscriber_db = 'CDB';

docs.title: 🛠 6. Automate Checking All Replication Subscriptions at Once
docs.text:
Run this script in the distribution database to loop through all relevant subscriptions:

Not working Need to update

SQL
DECLARE @publisher sysname, @publisher_db sysname, @publication sysname, @subscriber sysname, @subscriber_db sysname;

DECLARE subscription_cursor CURSOR FOR
SELECT 
    a.publisher,
    a.publisher_db,
    a.publication,
    s.subscriber,
    s.subscriber_db
FROM MSpublications a
JOIN MSsubscriptions s ON a.publication_id = s.publication_id
WHERE a.publisher_db IN ('DB01', 'DB02')
  AND s.subscriber_db = 'CDB';

OPEN subscription_cursor;
FETCH NEXT FROM subscription_cursor INTO @publisher, @publisher_db, @publication, @subscriber, @subscriber_db;

WHILE @@FETCH_STATUS = 0
BEGIN
    PRINT 'Checking pending commands for publication: ' + @publication + ', subscriber: ' + @subscriber;
    EXEC sp_replmonitorsubscriptionpendingcmds 
        @publisher = @publisher,
        @publisher_db = @publisher_db,
        @publication = @publication,
        @subscriber = @subscriber,
        @subscriber_db = @subscriber_db;

    FETCH NEXT FROM subscription_cursor INTO @publisher, @publisher_db, @publication, @subscriber, @subscriber_db;
END

CLOSE subscription_cursor;
DEALLOCATE subscription_cursor;

docs.title: 🧱 7. Analyze Replicated Tables for Performance Issues
⚠️ 8. View Replication Agent Errors and History

SQL
USE distribution;
GO

SELECT 
    h.agent_id,
    a.name AS agent_name,
    h.runstatus,
    h.duration,
    h.start_time,
    h.time AS end_time,
    h.comments,
    h.xact_seqno,
    h.delivery_latency,
    h.delivery_rate,
    h.delivered_commands,
    h.delivered_transactions,

FROM dbo.MSdistribution_history h

docs.title: 🧹 11. Recommendations for Performance Optimization
docs.text:
• Avoid daily snapshots unless necessary.
  • Schedule replication agents during off-peak hours.
  • Index frequently updated columns in replicated tables.
  • Consider splitting problematic tables into separate publications.
  • Clean up old/unused subscriptions and publications.
  • Regularly monitor and maintain the distribution database size.
